captions.text:
Let's just imagine you've
sailed for days and days to
find a really sweet, secluded
anchorage.
To make things even better,

there's a breathtaking beach
just around the corner.

You decide to chill out for a
while and relax,

let loose, maybe even have a
few parties!

You commandeer the abandoned
fishing hut to set up your bar
and run into a problem.
You've got plenty of mixers,

..but you're a little short on
the good stuff.

Do you leave and sail away to
the nearest store which is
hundreds of miles and days
away???
HELL NO!!!

"Ok, first step of the process
is we need to sanitize

everything. So here we have our
sterilizing stuff.

And we use 10 mils of this to 1
litre of water

We pop it in here. And we use a
small brush
to clean it. It's allgood!"
(laughing)

"Alright it's step 2 of the
distillation process. We need
to mix our 3 ingredients
together that make liquor.

That would be sugar, water and
yeast.

So we get 8 kilos of suagr,
heat up 5 litres of water and
dissolve it really good.
Pour that, bugs outta here..

Pour that into our sanitized
jug,

And we fill the rest of the jug
up with 25 litres with normal
water

"Alright, so our sugar has been
absorbed by the water..

and the temperature is down to
under 32 degrees

centigrade. So we're ready to
start the next step, which is
adding the yeast
to the sugar water.

So the first thing I'm gonna do
is put in our little alcohol
meter which is going to tell us
when the brew is finished
put that one there..

It kind of tells us the amount
of potential alcohol we can
have in the mixture

This one right now is sitting
down here..

At dessert wine, which is good,
cos after we're finished, we
wanna have about

20% alcohol by body, before we
can distill it.
So that's all sorted!
This is 'alcotec 48

hour turbo yeast'! But if we
let it run for 5 days,
we get 5% more alcohol

so we're patient. That's what
we're gonna do.
Smells lovely

Alright, so we're checking on
our brew here. It's been 5 days
now.

And it's starting to smell
really good!

It has that alcoholy beer,
kinda yeasty smell!

Which means its doing its
things, and the yeast is
definitely converting the sugar
into alcohol.

We got some bubbles going on.
And the alcohol content is..
It is all the way at the top..
At strong wine, so..

we're getting there! Maybe
about another day or so..

And then we'd be able to run a
batch through. Getting close!"
"So this step 3

of the Delos Moonshining
Production!

And here we have our mash, our
fermented mash.. whatever you
wanna call it.

And we're gonna pour it into
our still here.

And we're gonna start
distilling some alcohol.

And then this is the still
head, so this a reflex still

And basically the element heats
up

the fermented water, sugar and
yeast that we've put in here,
and then the vapors rise

up the column. And we circulate
water through it

to control the temperature. So
we just run the hose from
outside into this

And since we're in a boat, we
put the other end back in the
water tank

so we don't waste our water.
And then we get our pure alcohol

out of here, and monitor the
temperature here.

So when we run the still, we
take advantage of the generator

running and we load it as much
as possible. So we always do a
lot things

So we're making hot water,
we're charging the battery,

We're gonna do laundry, and
we're making water!

Fresh water. 
So I just turned on the diesel
unit

which is cranking out about 180
litres an hour right now
which is really good!

As soon it switches to green. 
ahh perfect, and we're now
making fresh drinking water!

It just so happens that the
still takes the same amount

of time of the laundry machine,
so it's very convenient.

So the stills just coming up a
temperature now

to the point where we get some
of first bad stuff out

which is the methanol. Which
you can see..
dripping right there

This is the stuff we DO NOT
want to drink
Because it's the first 50 mils

So we'll just wait till it gets
up to 50,
and then we'll toss that one.

Since this is basically poison,
we save it in little bottles

in the one harm we would be
pirates

A little splash in the face
with this and they'll be
running!

Ok, so now that we've got the
poison out of there,

Everything we collect from now
on,

is beautiful, delicious, pure
alcohol.

Most of our alcohol between 80
and 90. We never go over 90

because then you start getting
poisons from the tailing's, so
as long as you stick

in those two ranges, you'll be
good.

I've been running for about 2.5
hours here,

And we're up above the 750 mil
mark

So I think we'll be getting to
1 litre pretty soon!
(Coughs)

"Ok... woah... pretty strong
stuff!"

"WOAH! F *ck me! You could
drunk just on that! OH MY GOD!"

After our distillation is
complete we use activated
charcoal to remove any
impurities

and taste before bottling and
flavoring.

The filter top is basically
just an old Martini Shaker we
drilled a hole in.

The alcohol pushes it's way
through this activated charcoal
filter.

It takes a while at one drop
per second, but what you get
out is really pure and tastes
great!

At this point our alcohol is
about 85%

and still way too strong to
drink.

We use an alcohol meter and
water from the boat desalinator
to dillute it down to something
reasonanable,
like 40%.
Next we break out the kit

which contains all our wood
chips, flavors, and essences.

We measure and mix different
flavors,

,depending on what we're going
for.

How about a vanilla cherry
vodka?

Or maybe a delicious fresh
mango infused vodka?

Maybe an almond cherry bourbon
is more your style?

"So what are we doing over
here?"
"Some flavoured vodka"

"It's gonna be some watermelon
vodka"
"Some lime in there"

And finally, the most important
step of all!

Enjoying the fruits of your
labor!

"Is it on?
"Yeah"

"In step 2!"
(laughs)
"So welcome to step 3 of the..
"Look at me!"
"You know what time it is?"
"It's business time!"

comments.text:
Another comment. Filtering, a waste of time (and alcohol). You are using a 
REFLUX still which is very effective in stripping away the volatiles so the 
spirit without double distilling will be about as good as it gets. We run 
the SAME reflux head (also on a yacht!) to 98c then back blend 6lts from 
8kg sugar. The best you can get. There are no "POISONS" in your spirit 
either heads or tails unless YOU add them. Use of lead solder in making 
stills was another source of real poison but commercially made reflux heads 
produce nothing but DRINKABLE hooch from start to finish. (I have been 
doing this for 22 years and still have 20/20 vision!)﻿
comments.author: Steve Notnow

comments.text:
The MYTH continues..you can not Can Not CAN NOT make methanol through 
distillation of yeast produced ETHANOL. You just threw away 50mils of your 
highest ETHANOL concentration your still will produce (it tapers off as 
time goes by). This moonshine legend comes from those idiots that add meths 
to their spirit. Think for a minute: you drink a bottle of wine, you don't 
go blind. So are you saying distill that bottle of wine and you will!!?? 
DUH!﻿
comments.author: Steve Notnow

comments.text:
In the Distill process, why can't you drink the first 50 mil of the 
alcohol? Why is it poisonous?﻿

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcohol

+Nathan Pablo Hey Nathan, The still we're using in this video is a 5 Litre

recommend them ;) Hope this helps, Cheers and fair winds! Josje ~ SV Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Trying some of the turbo yeast as we speak. Thanks for the great ideas! 
 I've designed my own still out of an old pressure cooker, and it seems to 
be really workable.  After all, this isn't rocket science, and it seems 
that as long as everything is clean and you use purified water, and watch 
your temperatures, all should go well.

Now, on to figuring out all those interesting recipes!﻿

comments.author: Brandon Williams

comments.text:
I don't see the value of making it v. buying it because all of the supplies 
weigh as much and take up as much room to stowe on board as ready-made 
alcohol. Plus, what's the difference between sailng a hundred miles to buy 
sugar and yeast required to make the mash, and sailing a hundred miles to 
buy alcohol?  lol  ﻿
comments.author: Castaway

comments.text:
And it's way more fun to make your own.  You're only limited by what you 
can get your hands on for a sugar source.  You can make some very exotic 
stuff that you'll never find in stores.  In the tropics you could make 
mango brandy which I doubt even exists in stores.  Or a blend of tropical 
fruit brandy.
comments.author: BrentRF

comments.text: Oh, okay, that makes sense!  I had no idea alcohol was that expensive.  :)
comments.author: Castaway

comments.text:
Hey Castaway- Valid thoughts but here's some other reasons we debated 
before gong this route....  In this part of the world (Australia in 
particular) alcohol is SUPER EXPENSIVE!  1 liter of local Bundy rum was 
setting us back about $65.00.  For the same amount we were going to 
provision for 2 months of sailing up the coast we were able to buy the 
still and enough supplies to last us for a year.  Then there's also the 
aspect that it's just a whole lot of fun.  It's a great hobby and we really 
love experimenting with different techniques, flavors.  We can carry yeast 
and sugar to last us a year, and make our own water with the desal so for 
us it just makes a lot of sense.  Thanks for watching!Cheers,Brian

comments.text:
+Chris S/V Saltrun
Hey Chris, I think the still we have was only available at physical stores 
in Australia.  The smallest, most portable still they have is the Air 
Still.  It's even smaller and doesn't use cooling water which is a bonus.  
Still Spirits just sent us one and it looks pretty sweet, although we 
haven't run a batch through it yet.  I know they can mark it as a "water 
purifier" to ship it just about anywhere in the world :)  Hope this helps, 
and happy sailing and distilling!

comments.author: Glenn S

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos well you used refined white sugar, which comes from sugar 
cain. by definition spirits made from sugar cain or derivatives of it is 
rum. to be vodka it would have to be made from potatoes.

but I'm just being silly here, because once you get up to that strength and 
with flavors added, it really doesn't matter what it's made from.

comments.text:
Try to add just a few blueberries two or three to your mash. It adds a 
little flavor, sugar for the yeast, and some anti-oxies for the following 
day. Do it right and you'll smooth any flavor. ﻿

comments.text:
hi this is mick i have the same five liter pot still as u but i have a 
tower on top witch brings the alcohol out at 96 percent i use to 30 liter 
fermentation barrels and put 20 liters of water in each and 5 kilos of 
surger  in each and i put half off one packet of yeast in each the same 
brand u use and get 8 liters of alcohol its a good way to save money cheers 
r u Australians     ﻿

comments.text:
Hey Loren- The trip started in Seattle in 2009 so it's been a long but

comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Awesome videos Brian! I'm also in Seattle and was wondering if you learned 
to sail here and if so any suggestions where a newbie should learn? Cheers. 
﻿
comments.author: dwntwn27

comments.text:
Hello!  Yes- you should absolutely check out the Center For Wooden Boats on 
Lake Union.  Great place to learn some dinghy sailing.  I started out here 
then ended up joining a race crew to really learn some sailing.  Not sure 
if they still do it but in the summers there are fun races with a BBQ 
afterwards at Elliot Bay Marina.  Figure out what night that is and show up 
and just walk around.  You're bound to meet lot's of like minded people.  
Especially if you stay for the BBQ after when the beer is flowing :)  Oh 
yea- and there's also the Duck Dodge on Lake Union during the summer.  
Lot's of chances to sail on small keel boats in a fun atmosphere here.Fair 
Winds!BrianS\V Delos
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Can you please make a video that answers these questions:  How much do you 
spend on average per month, per person or total to do your trip?  how do 
you earn money to facilitate your travels? How would you recommend someone 
to do what you do?  Your videos have inspired me and I am buying my boat 
and working to setting sail next summer.. maybe we can meet?﻿
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Delos crew,

I actually have been brainstorming a few ideas for you guys to make some 
money for your travels. I have an outline for how the raffle could work if 
you are interested..  I also have a couple ways to get you guys/gals some 
sponsors and use your youtube channel to get some traveling funds as well 
as a few other ideas. My email is: powelltimothyd@gmail.com  shoot me an 
email and I would be happy to help out. I am saving money everyday right 
now to head out on my own.. I hope to meet up with you guys by fall or 
spring of next year. Maybe we can start the Delos Armada?
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
Wow that's an excellent idea!  You know I was thinking of something very 
similar a few months ago.  I'm glad someone else thinks this would work.  
Ok, we'll put some thought into this and see if we can come up with 
something!Thanks again!Brian
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
+Brian SV Delos Bro-heim, thanks for taking time to answer my questions, it 
was very helpful.  I wanted to make a couple final comments!  I was 
thinking that you guys should have a raffle.  You can sell tickets to all 
of your loyal fans and if the raffle meets a certain figure, you can give 
someone a spot on your boat for a predetermined amount of time..  They will 
have to buy their airfare, but food, room, and board, will be included!  
You can earn some extra travel money this way!
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
Hey there!  Thanks so much for the comments and watching the videos!  You 
should definitely do it man, you will love it!  It's not a video but we did 
write a blog post about this.  Check out 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-1by-brian.html 
for the history and 
http://svdelos.blogspot.com/2013/12/how-do-we-afford-to-sail-part-2-by-brian.html 
for how we make ends meet now.  Best of luck on your plans and hope we have 
a chance to cross paths!Cheers,BrianS\V Delos

comments.author: smp22

comments.text:
would probably not distill alcohol on a boat, but at least it's legal if 
you are in international waters, though can't think that the coast guard 
etc.. would be thrilled.
Personally because of the health risk ,I would use a better thermometer for 
example a scientific one that gives a few decimal place for temp readings. 
Also I would get a barometer (accurate one) and adjust for air pressure, 
though you're on the ocean not climbing a mountain. I'm just really 
protective of my life. Of course that defeats the drinking part.﻿
comments.author: anomy safad

comments.text:
+thopkins22 You are absoluetly right.  This has been such a great debate.. 
You are a genious!!  I like that you argue semantics when I merely said 
that it was legal to make booze..  Feel free to not respond, because not 
only am I bored of this conversation, but I am sure no one else cares..
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
You specifically stated moonshine.  Moonshine is not a style of spirit.  It 
is simply a spirit for consumption that has not been taxed and was produced 
in an unlicensed still.

Hence, moonshine is illegal.

Anything you buy at a store labeling itself as moonshine, is not...because 
it was made legally and taxed like every other spirit.
comments.author: thopkins22

comments.text:
+thopkins22 You are confused..  I never said that it was practical!!  I 
said that is was legal!!  I was right and you guys are bringing up points 
that only prove that it is legal! I am not saying that anyone wants to do 
the paperwork, or deal with the taxes, etc..  I just said it was legal and 
that the Govt wants their share!  So thank you for proving me right
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
+Film Fanaddicts That's not accurate.  In the United States you are not 
allowed to distill alcohol without going through ridiculous processes, 
expenses, and taxation.  The US criminal code has since been posted for you 
to read.  It's quite clear.

The ATF has a FAQ as well as help lines that you can call to clarify if you 
don't believe us.
comments.author: thopkins22

comments.text:
Moonshine is 100% legal in America and in nearly all countries outside of 
Central Asia!!  You are allowed to make it for personal use!  It is only 
illegal if you sell it (govt wants their taxes).  You can even give 
smoonshine away, but you cannot sell it!  So please do not make comments 
such as the coast gaurd will not being thrilled if you do not know what you 
are talking about!!  Furthermore, you obviously have never made shine or 
you would know that it is very low tech and your scientific decimal 
readings and barometer comments is just ridiculous.. Think before you speak 
and your life will probably be safer!
comments.author: Film Fanaddicts

comments.text:
Anomy, why would you adjust for barometric pressure on a boat, wtf?? You're 
AT SEA LEVEL, duh!
Alcohol evaporates at EXACTLY 78°C, water at EXACTLY 100°C. Even if your 
thermometer is 5 degrees out you're still fine (I've never seen this). Most 
digital thermometers are within 0.5°C. If you're uncertain just boil some 
water and see if it registered 100°C at roughly sea level, if not, 
calibrate. In fact, on a boat is probably one of the best places to distil 
alcohol. The yeast mixture creates alcohol to a maximum of about 20%, then 
the alcohol kills the yeast, then you distil, easy. If you heat to say 85°C 
it's not like you're evaporating anything else apart from alcohol in the 
stile. Very safe as long as you dilute it with water. Good work guys! I 
believe to make the pirate's rum they used a 50/50 molasses/sugar mix.
Source: I just did a course on molecular gastronomy at Harvard.
comments.author: Kinetic79au

comments.text:
As a funny aside when we tried it for the first time due to what we'd heard 
from bootlegging, etc. we were still a bit nervous so only a few of us 
tried it.  That way someone could take care of us if something went really, 
really wrong.  Silly, but never too safe right?
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
Yup, you're right.  We did the research when we considered buying the still 
and figured with this process there was virtually no way we could poison 
ourselves, short of straight drinking what we should throw away from 
multiple, multiple batches.Basically we trust in math and chemistry.  
Thanks for the very informative comment and watching!
comments.author: SV Delos Crew

comments.text:
+anomy safad Understood!  I'd be nervous as hell for the first few drinks 
myself.....
comments.author: thopkins22

comments.text:
There's so little methanol created when fermenting alcohol from pure sugar 
that it's almost not a concern at all.

Distilling your own spirits is not this risk laden thing that several 
generations worth of propaganda has most of us believing it is.  The reason 
people used to suffer optical nerve damage was because a lot of the old 
bootleggers diluted their product with methylated spirits to increase their 
profit margins.  Don't do that, take away the first 50-200ml of the 
distillate just to be safe, keep the temperature a little lower to avoid 
the pentanol and other fusel oils and you'll be fine.

A fatal dose of methanol is between 100/250ml in a day.  That much wasn't 
created in that whole damned batch.  Same with the other fusel oils like 
pentanol...that's like 58L of booze.  You'd die of plain old ethanol 
poisoning LONG before the other things got to be too much.

And regarding barometric pressure...all of the boiling/evaporative 
temperatures are at sea level.  The pressure doesn't change enough between 
weather systems to matter for what they're doing.  They have a large range 
of safe temperatures in which to distill before they start getting the less 
desirable distillates.


I'm not a distiller, and this isn't advice.  I'm just an engineer who likes 
booze and chemistry.

If it's ever legalized for personal consumption where I live, I'd love to 
try my hand at it.

also produced in the fermentation process. This can be detected by how much 
the odor was reduced after charcoal filtering.﻿

Oh definitely yes to fire.  We use the stuff we throw out to burn trash.   
And no not really to going blind.  You'd have to drink soooooo much to get

days when people intentionally cut the alcohol with stuff you should throw 
away to boost their profits.  Much like today's drug dealers.
